content: Position of admiral within the armed forces in Malay and Indonesia areas The **Laksamana** ([Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): لقسامان‎) is a position within the armed forces, similar to the position of [admiral](/wiki/Admiral) in [Malay](/wiki/Malay_people) sultanates and in present-day countries like [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesian_Navy) and [Malaysia](/wiki/Royal_Malaysian_Navy). Since South East Asia was part of [Indosphere](/wiki/Indosphere) of [Greater India](/wiki/Greater_India) since earlier, during and after the Hinduised [Srivijaya](/wiki/Srivijaya) empire, Hindu titles based on Sanskrit were used. The word Laksamana originated from *[Lakshmana](/wiki/Lakshmana)*, a figure in the Hindu epic of [Ramayana](/wiki/Ramayana). ## Malacca Sultanate The *Laksamana* in the [Malacca Sultanate](/wiki/Malacca_Sultanate) was a key figure responsible for safeguarding the Sultanate’s maritime security, particularly along the vital China-India trade route in the [Straits of Malacca](/wiki/Strait_of_Malacca), which was the lifeline of the empire. As the commander of the Malaccan [fleet](/wiki/Naval_fleet), the *Laksamana* held significant authority, outranked only by the *[Bendahara](/wiki/Bendahara)* (prime minister) and the [Sultan](/wiki/Sultan). In addition to his naval duties, the *Laksamana* also served in roles akin to a modern-day head of diplomatic affairs and vice [minister of war](/wiki/Ministry_of_defence). The legendary *[Hikayat Hang Tuah](/wiki/Hikayat_Hang_Tuah)* records *Laksamana* [Hang Tuah](/wiki/Hang_Tuah) being sent on numerous diplomatic missions to destinations such as the [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire) in [South India](/wiki/South_India), [China](/wiki/China), [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand), and even the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire). Similarly, the *[Rekidai Hoan](/wiki/Rekidai_H%C5%8Dan)*, an official record from the [Ryukyu Kingdom](/wiki/Ryukyu_Kingdom), mentions a Malaccan diplomatic envoy led by "Lezoumana" or "Lo-hsi-ma-na", reflecting the *Laksamana’s* international significance. Historical sources, including the *[Suma Oriental](/wiki/Suma_Oriental)* and the *[Malay Annals](/wiki/Malay_Annals)*, identify only three named *Laksamana* during the Sultanate's history. Hang Tuah served under [Sultan Mansur Shah](/wiki/Mansur_Shah_of_Malacca), followed by Khoja Hussain and [Hang Nadim](/wiki/Hang_Nadim), who served under [Sultan Mahmud Shah](/wiki/Mahmud_Shah_of_Malacca). ## Modern-day usage ### Navy and coast guard In modern times, the word refers to a rank in [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei) (by the [Royal Brunei Navy](/wiki/Royal_Brunei_Navy)), in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia) (by the [Indonesian Navy](/wiki/Indonesian_Navy) and [Indonesian Maritime Security Agency](/wiki/Indonesian_Maritime_Security_Agency)) and in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) (by the [Royal Malaysian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Malaysian_Navy) and [Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency](/wiki/Malaysian_Maritime_Enforcement_Agency)). The common grades for "Laksamana" title are: 1. *Laksamana armada* (lit. '[Fleet admiral](/wiki/Fleet_admiral)', a five-star rank used by [Royal Malaysian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Malaysian_Navy)) 2. *Laksamana besar* (lit. '[Grand admiral](/wiki/Grand_admiral)', a five-star rank used by [Indonesian Navy](/wiki/Indonesian_Navy)) 3. *Laksamana* (lit. '[Admiral](/wiki/Admiral)', a four-star rank) 4. *Laksamana madya* (lit. 'Middle admiral', "[Vice Admiral](/wiki/Vice_Admiral)", a three-star rank) 5. *Laksamana muda* (lit. 'Young/junior admiral', "[Rear Admiral](/wiki/Rear_Admiral)", a two-star rank) 6. *Laksamana pertama* (lit. 'First admiral', a one-star rank, [Rear Admiral](/wiki/Rear_Admiral) or [Commodore](/wiki/Commodore_(rank))) Rank*Laksamana armada* or *Laksamana besar**Laksamana**Laksamana madya**Laksamana muda**Laksamana pertama*Admiral of the FleetAdmiralVice AdmiralRear admiralCommodore**[Royal Brunei Navy](/wiki/Royal_Brunei_Navy)****[Indonesian Navy](/wiki/Indonesian_Navy)** **[Indonesian Maritime Security Agency](/wiki/Indonesian_Maritime_Security_Agency)****[Royal Malaysian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Malaysian_Navy)** **[Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency](/wiki/Malaysian_Maritime_Enforcement_Agency)** ## Usage other than as military title In Brunei, [Laksamana College of Business](/wiki/Laksamana_College_of_Business) ([Malay](/wiki/Malay_language): *Kolej Perniagaan Laksamana*) is an accredited private university college established in 2003. The college also acted as a subsidiary college of the [Kensington College of Business](/wiki/Kensington_College_of_Business). In Indonesia, [Laksamana mengamuk](/wiki/Laksamana_mengamuk) is a drink from [Riau](/wiki/Riau). This drink is made from [mango](/wiki/Mango) mixed with [coconut milk](/wiki/Coconut_milk) and [sugar](/wiki/Sugar). Usually served during [Ramadan](/wiki/Ramadan). In Malaysia, [Laksamana class](/wiki/Laksamana-class_corvette) is a class of small [missile](/wiki/Missile) [corvettes](/wiki/Corvette) comprising four ships in service with the [Royal Malaysian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Malaysian_Navy). As of 5 June 2025[update], two ships of the Laksamana class are serving in the 24th Corvette Squadron of the Royal Malaysian Navy, while the remaining two were decommissioned. In Philippines, *Laksamana*, along with its [Hispanicized](/wiki/Hispanization) forms *Lacsamana* and *Laxamana*, is a [family name](/wiki/Family_name) among the [Pampangan people](/wiki/Pampangan_people) of the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines) and their descendants. - [Bendahara](/wiki/Bendahara) - [Syahbandar](/wiki/Syahbandar) - [Temenggung](/wiki/Temenggung) This [Southeast Asian history](/wiki/Southeast_Asian_history)-related article is a stub.
